data.title: Meaning of Westphalia in the 18th century
data.meta_description: Here on the top right is the marriage registration of my ancestors, in 1718 in the city of Groningen ... Calaats in Bohemia, is also a mystery for me.
data.text:
In 1180, at the fall of Heinrich dem Löwen, the Herzogtum Westfalen (Duchy of Westphalia) was formed from the southwestern part of Sachsen (eastern Sauerland with northern bordering areas south of the river Lippe). At that time, the Duchy of Westphalia belonged to the Prince-Bishopric of Cologne.

From 1803 (Reichsdeputationshauptschluss) the Duchy of Westphalia came to the Landgraviate of Hesse-Kassel and was one of the three divisions of the Landgraviate.

In 1807-1810 Westphalia was broken up and the northern part came to the Grand Duchy of Berg, the southern part to Hesse-Darmstadt.

In 1815/1816, the area and other territories (roughly today's Westphalia) fell to Prussia and from then until 1945 formed the Province of Westphalia of the Kingdom/Free State of Prussia. In 1949, it was merged with the Prussian Rhine Province to form the federal state of North Rhine-Westphalia.

The Königreich Westphalen (Kingdom of Westphalia) was created in 1807 (the Duchy of Westphalia was never part of this kingdom); it disintegrated in 1813 and most of its parts went to the re-established Hessen-Kassel.
